content:
Quite a soaking once again. About 36 hours of off and on rain. Approximately an inch to two inches through Wednesday morning. There is a deficit for this month so far but this wet spell should resolve
that. Rainfall is running at or above normal for the region for the year and the long-term drought is essentially over for most of the area.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: US National Weather Service New York NY

content: 1/2 to 1-1/2" of rain so far and the worst is yet to come for some areas. Radar shows the orange/red area just offshore and it is moving ccw or 'spiraling in' towards land. This area has rainfall rates exceeding 1" per hour. WCBS Newsradio 880 areas already getting moderate to heavy rain may see 'flood advisory' conditions with poor-drainage, street and urban flooding the primary concerns. Easterly winds are also gusting over 30 mph

content:
A special 36th anniversary edition of #tbt. Today marks 36 years with #wcbs880 WCBS Newsradio 880 and to celebrate, I decided to humble myself and post a few #embarrassing photos üò≥ from the early days, in this montage with the great 880, now celebrating its 50th !!  üò≤üëåü•Ç

A huge 'thank you' to current and previous bosses and managers including Tim Scheld, @Jonathan Clark, Scott Herman, Marc Rayfield, Crys Quimby, Harvey Nagler, Bernard Gershon.....every colleague I've worked with on air and behind the scenes...and of course YOU, the listeners and followers of this page as your source of news, weather, traffic and sports.‚òùÔ∏èüëç

So on this gloomy, foggy morning‚òÅ üåÇ, let's spread a little sunshine üå§Ô∏è and celebrate! üòé.  We've come a long way.

Double-chai. Can we make it another 36? üòâ

content: Storms are expected to weaken somewhat when approaching the coast but showers and scattered thunderstorms still likely around here, especially from about midnight, on.............
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: US National Weather Service Eastern Region HQ

content:
The squall line is weakening and breaking up in central PA. Cells are moving up the squall line while the line presses east into our 'marine' environment.
However....it is still strong, producing gusts over 50 mph and torrential downpours. I've posted the HRRR (which did a fantastic job with the late Friday night/early Sat morning storms) and it is definitely more robust on the latest runs, arriving between 10pm and 2am from western jersey to eastern L.I.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: Photos from Craig Allen On-Air Inc's post

content:
60¬∞. Nice number for our WCBS Newsradio 880 listeners and PIX 11 viewers but it's all relative. When it's early in spring- like late March or early April- we look forward to it; it feels great. üå∑
But when it's May and we've already enjoyed many days in the 70's and several even in the 80's, 60¬∞ suddenly doesn't feel as nice. üòí
60¬∞ , +/- 5¬∞, is going to be the median daytime high over the next week to ten days- if not more- based on the weather pattern that is setting up. Winter lovers would rejoice over this alignment of the jet stream if this was January or February ‚ùÑÔ∏è but it's May and I for one want to work around the garden without having to wear jacket.  üòï
Known as a blocking pattern with a ridge out west and a trof in the east, blocked essentially near Greenland, cold air in Canada can't do anything else but funnel down into the northeast. With the stronger sun at this time of year, that creates a very unstable atmosphere so clouds and showers keep popping up. All models indicate this 'cold Low' to cut off from the main jet stream and just wobble around for days. üëé

Tonight will be chilly and a frost advisory is posted for counties in blue. Most likely spots will be the deeper valleys, well inland where the cold air can collect. 

Tomorrow will be dry but with increasing clouds and veering winds, it will likely be a few degrees lower than today.

A soaking rain is on the way, üåßÔ∏è starting late Thursday night, right through Friday into Friday night. Maps posted indicate an average 1-2 inch rainfall with locally higher amounts. As you can surmise, the drought is essentially over for our region.

Then the weekend will feel and look like we stepped a few weeks backwards in time to a variable cloud cover, hit & miss showers and below normal temperatures. üò¶ The 6-10 day and 8-14 day maps keep below normal temperatures going the first half of this month. üò± We'll see but to me, just hitting 60 is no longer acceptable....but the garden should look good. üåøüåπüåæüåº
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: Photos from Craig Allen On-Air Inc's post

content:
#FlashFlood Warning through 4:pm. 1 to 2" already in warned area and another 1 to 2" likely. The next area of 'training' rain  moving up  is as torrential if not heavier than the last couple hours. Very appropriate that this is Flash Flood Awareness Week. Turn Around/ Don't Drown !! 
Easterlies are gusting over 40 mph, especially near the coast.
#Stormy conditions across the #wcbs880 WCBS Newsradio 880 area will diminish towards evening though cool and showery weather is expected to last into early next week.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: Photos from Craig Allen On-Air Inc's post

content:
The deluge is over but flooding lingers and additional rain is likely. Showers, drizzle and fog for almost anywhere overnight and HRRR is showing a couple rounds of steadier rain, especially over L.I. and CT overnight.The model has been superb lately. 
Here is a list of rainfall reports from the NWS/OKX. Thanks to all for the reports. Check the link below to see if your town is noted. Many rainfall records were set, including NYC, EWR, ISP, BDR, JFK & LGA

Here's our latest F/B live to keep you covered until then................
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: PIX 11

content:
It's Hurricane Preparedness Week! To mark the occasion, the Hurricane Awareness Tour will be along the east coast this week and stop #2 is right here in our backyard at ISP- MacArthur Airport tomorrow- Monday 5/8. I'll be there tomorrow though I can't be sure what time. It should be a fascinating tour, lecture and chance to speak with the hurricane pros. The details are in the links below:

https://www.weather.gov/wrn/hurricane-preparedness

http://www.weather.gov/okx/2017HAT
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: Hurricane Preparedness Week 2017

content:
Spent midday at L.I. MacArthur Airport. Day #2 of the Hurricane Awareness Tour. Informative and fascinating looking at the equipment and listening to the stories from pilots and crew members of the storms they've been through.
This is an interview of the NHC's director Dr Rick Knabb and our NWS/OKX MIC I. Ross Dickman. Winds were gusting 30-35 mph and someone should have thought about a windscreen for the microphone, lol

My main camera/phone bit the dust today so I went to my backup and am trying to post my interview with the pilot, later.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: NOAA NWS National Hurricane Center

content:
A great voice and superb news anchor has been silenced by cancer. You probably heard his voice most recently on 1010 WINS. A program director at WALK-FM and you might remember he did traffic on 880.
Such a genuine, friendly person filled with stories and kindness. RIP Gene and condolences to the family.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: 1010 WINS

content:
An out-of-season nor'easter will drench the #wcbs880 WCBS Newsradio 880 area Saturday into Saturday night. Much of the area will receive an average of 1 to 2" of rain. Like a winter snowstorm, we'll have to watch and determine where the heaviest bands of rain set up. Some places may pick up 1/2 to 1" of rain while others are soaked with 2 to 3".  Winds may gust above 30 mph, especially along the coast.

The maps show the distribution of the rain and also show the center of the storm moving away from the coast on Sunday. This should lead to slowly improving weather though leftover showers are still expected on Mothers Day. However, the final map is the 6-10 day outlook and that shows temperatures are likely to be above normal as soon as this last storm leaves and this stubborn pattern breaks down. It will finally feel like May and possibly even more like June
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: Photos from Craig Allen On-Air Inc's post

content:
We've got the New York Mets game on PIX 1111. I'd love to go on with our 10pm newscast on time but it's a close game with Mets up 3-2 in the top of the 5th.
So here's some weather info for you now to help plan for Mother's Day and the week ahead. You'll be amazed how much it will change in a matter of days!
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: PIX 11

content:
The Saturday soaker has turned into a magnificent day for Mom....so far. There is still a very good chance of showers and thunderstorms in parts of the area later this afternoon and evening though. 
Wishing all the Mom's a wonderful day !!

content: See how fast it changed? Showers and thunderstorms roaming many parts of the PIX 11 tri-state region. Bar-b-queing for Mom? Take cover. Downpours with several reports of wind damage coming in. Camera shows it approaching. Svr Tstm Wrng (Orange) in effect until 5:45.

content:
It is beautiful out there.
A W/NW wind should even keep the sea breeze at bay until late day, if then, so even LI and the CT coast will warm up.
Wed & Thu might not fit your top 10 criteria since it will get quite warm and more humid.

So ENJOY today!! We earned it.

title: Timeline Photos

content: May? Not even normal for August in some cases. Many record highs smashed, after record overnight warmth. One more hot one then a return to an early spring feel for the weekend.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: US National Weather Service New York NY

content:
First May heat wave in 16 years. Plus more high temp and 'high, low-temp, records broken today. But that's it...we won't be talking about heat waves again for another week or two at least.
Stay cool this evening. Isolated thunderstorms for next couple hours then open the windows and turn off the a/c late tonight.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: Timeline Photos

content:
For those of you keeping score, out of the dozens and dozens of sources of info to use to make a 24 hour forecast, only 1 model picked up on today's clouds and showers.üòí The #HRRR model  has been showing today's scattered showers since midday yesterday.üòÆ Yet, apparently none of us wanted to buy into that outlier solution.ü§îü§ê Well, once again-as it has so many times this spring- the HRRR wins and we lose.üò† It's not a major system; the much cooler weather rushed in as expected, but now you'll need to dodge a few raindrops as well. The proof is posted showing noon thru 2pm then the current radar.

Tomorrow is a little better but Monday still looks like a wet day.
name: Craig Allen On-Air Inc
title: Photos from Craig Allen On-Air Inc's post
